importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The game took place on October 17, 2025, highlighting a significant matchup between veteran quarterbacks in the NFL, reinforcing the idea that aging professionals can still perform at a high level.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The game occurred on a Thursday night, specifically during the 'Thursday Night Football' schedule, indicating it was a major televised event that draws national attention to the NFL's continued relevance beyond its younger stars.

keyTakeAways: Joe Flacco, 40 years old, outperformed Aaron Rodgers, 41 years old, in a high-scoring game between the Cincinnati Bengals and Pittsburgh Steelers, winning 33-31 in what was dubbed the 'Icy Hot Bowl'.

Flacco made his second start with the Bengals after being traded from the Cleveland Browns to replace Joe Burrow and Jake Browning due to injury, and delivered a strong performance with 342 yards passing, three touchdowns, and a game-winning field goal drive.

The Bengals rallied from a 10-0 deficit, scoring 20 consecutive points, and Flacco’s calm leadership in the final minutes was pivotal, including an 8-play, 52-yard drive that set up the winning field goal.

Aaron Rodgers had a productive night, throwing for 4 touchdowns and 2 interceptions, and moved into fifth place on the NFL all-time career passing yards list, passing Ben Roethlisberger with a 15-yard pass to Jaylen Warren.
The game was notable for showcasing veteran quarterbacks still thriving at the highest level, challenging the notion that the NFL is a 'young man’s game'.

Both teams had key performances: Ja’Marr Chase and Tee Higgins had strong receiving outings, and Chase Brown rushed for over 100 yards for the first time this season, signaling a revitalized Bengals offense.
The Bengals improved to 3-4 on the season, while the Steelers fell to 4-2 and remain atop the AFC North, with a critical game against the Green Bay Packers scheduled for Week 8.

namedEntities.name: Joe Flacco
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former quarterback, currently playing for the Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Flacco was the standout performer in the game, throwing for 342 yards and three touchdowns, and securing his first win in Cincinnati, showing that veteran quarterbacks can still dominate at the top level of the NFL.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Rodgers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rodgers was a key opponent to Flacco, showcasing his continued excellence with four touchdown passes and moving into fifth place on the NFL all-time career passing yards list.

namedEntities.name: Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional American football team in the NFL
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Bengals hosted the game and won 33-31, with a dramatic comeback and strong offensive performance, especially from their new quarterback Joe Flacco.

namedEntities.name: Pittsburgh Steelers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional American football team in the NFL
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Steelers lost the game 33-31 after a strong early lead, highlighting their vulnerability in a high-scoring, veteran-driven matchup.

namedEntities.name: Paycor Stadium
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Home stadium of the Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The game took place at Paycor Stadium, where the Bengals’ offensive and defensive performance was on full display, culminating in a dramatic final drive.

namedEntities.name: Ja’Marr Chase
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Wide receiver for the Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Chase had a standout game with 16 catches for 161 yards and a touchdown, contributing significantly to the Bengals’ offensive surge.

namedEntities.name: Tee Higgins
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Wide receiver for the Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Higgins had a season-high performance with six catches for 96 yards and a touchdown, reinforcing the Bengals' offensive depth and versatility.

namedEntities.name: Chase Brown
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Running back for the Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Brown rushed for over 100 yards for the first time this season, marking a turning point in the Bengals’ ground game and showing increased offensive balance.

namedEntities.name: Evan McPherson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: McPherson successfully converted the game-winning 36-yard field goal, which secured the Bengals’ victory in the final minutes.

namedEntities.name: Zac Taylor
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Head coach of the Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Taylor praised Flacco’s composure and leadership, particularly during the two-minute drive that led to the game-winning score, highlighting his coaching impact.

namedEntities.name: Cameron Heyward
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Heyward dubbed the matchup the 'Icy Hot Bowl' before the game, adding a memorable and symbolic name to the contest.

namedEntities.name: Joe Burrow
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Burrow’s long-term toe injury created the need for Flacco’s trade to the Bengals, which set the stage for Flacco’s debut and eventual victory.

namedEntities.name: Jake Browning
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Browning’s poor performance in Flacco’s debut led to the decision to bring in Flacco as a starter, showing the team’s reliance on veteran leadership.

namedEntities.name: Ben Roethlisberger
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback and all-time leading passer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rodgers passed Roethlisberger in the all-time career passing yards list during the game, marking a historic moment for the Steelers’ quarterback.

namedEntities.name: Brett Favre
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former NFL quarterback, holds fourth place in career passing yards
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rodgers is still over 7,000 yards behind Favre on the career passing yards list, showing that while Rodgers achieved a milestone, he still trails the all-time leader.

namedEntities.name: Green Bay Packers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: NFL team, rivals of the Steelers and former team of Aaron Rodgers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Packers are set to face the Steelers in a future matchup (Week 8), adding narrative tension and highlighting Rodgers’ career trajectory.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a high-stakes Thursday Night Football showdown dubbed the 'Icy Hot Bowl,' 40-year-old Joe Flacco outperformed 41-year-old Aaron Rodgers in a dramatic 33-31 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers. Flacco, traded to the Bengals to fill in after injuries to Joe Burrow and Jake Browning, delivered a standout performance with 342 yards and three touchdowns, including a game-winning drive in the final minutes. The Bengals, who had trailed 10-0, rallied with 20 consecutive points, with key contributions from Ja’Marr Chase and Tee Higgins. Rodgers, despite the loss, moved into fifth place on the NFL career passing yards list by passing Ben Roethlisberger, marking a historic milestone. The game underscored that the NFL remains a competitive arena for veteran athletes, reinforcing the relevance of experienced players in modern football. The Bengals improved to 3-4 on the season, while the Steelers fell to 4-2 and remain atop the AFC North, with a pivotal Sunday Night Football game against the Green Bay Packers scheduled for Week 8.
title: Joe Flacco outduels Aaron Rodgers in battle of elder statesmen as Bengals stun Steelers in ‘Icy Hot Bowl’
